title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section outlines a general rule where individuals are treated as having made a $500 payment towards the tax for the 2006 taxable year. The Secretary is required to remit this payment to taxpayers within 30 days of enactment. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens are not eligible for this payment. Additionally, there are conforming and clerical amendments made to related sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new provision related to the Oil Company Accountability Act. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 and the revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies under SEC. 3 will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 and the revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies under SEC. 3 will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, applicable integrated oil companies must increase the value of historic LIFO layers of inventories of petroleum products and decrease the cost of goods sold accordingly. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, the gross income will be adjusted. The layer adjustment amount is calculated based on the number of barrels of crude oil. The LIFO layer adjustment is calculated by multiplying $18.75 by the number of barrels of crude oil or barrel-of-oil equivalents in the layer. This adjustment does not constitute a change in accounting method and no additional tax will be imposed for underpayments related to the taxable year. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with specific production and revenue criteria. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one entity for tax purposes. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers are subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession and receive a specific economic benefit from that country. Any amount paid by such taxpayers to the country will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers receive a specific economic benefit from a foreign country or possession, subject to certain conditions regarding income tax. The term "generally applicable income tax" refers to taxes imposed on income derived from business activities within the country, excluding certain individuals. The term "large integrated oil company" is defined within this context. The term "large integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and a daily worldwide crude oil production of at least 500,000 barrels. The amendments apply to taxes in taxable years after the enactment date, except where contrary to US treaty obligations.
